newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek stocks firm 0.88pct on upbeat OTE.
newsitem.headline: Greek stocks firm 0.88pct on upbeat OTE.

text.p: Greek shares advanced 0.88 percent in quiet trading on Tuesday, clearing the 1,600 level and brokers said the broader market reflected a strong performance in OTE shares, currently going through a part-flotation procedure.
"The market was pulled higher by OTE which returned to the limelight today," said Mathios Doulos, a broker at Kyranis Securities.
Buying interest in the stock rose on rumours of satisfactory coverage by international institutionals of its privately placed tranche, he added.

"OTE dominated the scene today as some investors opted for direct purchase of OTE's shares from the bourse on early indications of a high oversubscription rate which would lower their allotments," said Nick Soulimiotis, broker at Pentedekas Securities.
Eased pressure on Alpha Credit also helped enliven the market, he added.
The book-building process for the private placement of state telecom OTE with international investors ends June 11.
It will be followed by a public offering 200 drachmas below the final book-building strike price.
Subscriptions to the public tranche will last between June 11-13 with an indicative price range to be announced later on Tuesday by lead underwriter and global coordinator National Bank.
The relative success of OTE's private placement and public subscription will determine the market's short-term direction, brokers said.
"The market will be delighted to see a over-subscription rate in excess of two or three times," said Soulimiotis.
The market was seen moving sideways for the rest of the week with investors remaining sidelined due to a temporary drop in liquidity caused by OTE's subscription.
"The market will remain stagnant for a few days because OTE's subscriptions have drained considerable liquidity, resulting in lower trading volumes," said Doulos.
"The market will remain rangebound in the 1,600 vicinity while subscriptions for OTE's part-flotation are running and cash is locked in bank accounts," said Soulimiotis.
The Athens general index added 0.88 percent or 14.05 points to close at 1,603.84 from Monday's 1,589.79, having peaked at 1,614.72 in early deals.
Banks led the market with a 0.95 percent climb. Industrials were mixed rising 0.13 percent while construction slipped 0.51 percent.
Turnover was subdued at 13.4 billion drachmas with only 3.4 million shares being traded.
Advancers led decliners 113 to 104 with 25 shares unchanged on 242 traded.
